div.p:
Narrator:
Hailey White never knew how dramatically her life would change when she celebrated summer's end at a party with her best friends.

Mom:
Hailey was always very outgoing, fun loving, everybody knew Hailey, everybody loved Hailey, and she had a lot of goals and accomplishments that she achieved. And that seemed to really give me as Mom a sense of she's doing the right thing, she's involved in the positive things that will help her in her decision making and making good choices.

Hailey:
When I graduated high school I enrolled at a technical college in Fondalack. Second to last year there, I drank a lot. Growing up in Burlen that's kind of what everybody did. There's not much for people to do, no movie theater, shopping mall, so we partied and we drank.

Jill:
I remember the summer of the accident, uh, we had been drinking a lot. There was a group of 8 of us from high school that always had girls' night weekly.

Narrator:
Every summer before school started, Hailey and her friends would attend one last party, where drinking was always an element.

Jill:
I remember Hailey telling me that she wanted to go home, and I told her well, that she probably shouldn't, she shouldn't drive.

Hailey:
I probably made it about a quarter mile down the road before I saw some people walking.

Randy:
We had a car down the road a couple miles, so we just figured we'd just walk down the road and get it. And uh, Hailey came over a hill I guess and hit me. I don't know, I don't remember nothing after that.

Hailey:
And I think I hit the brakes and I swerved, but the next thing I knew my windshield smashed, and then I stopped and I just screamed, and I knew who it was I graduated with him. And it was his 21st birthday that night.

Jill:
We must have been the first vehicle to pull up at the site of the accident afterwards. I got out of the vehicle and Hailey was screaming, hysterical.

Hailey:
His leg was obviously broken. I could see his bone sticking out of his leg. And I just said, I'm sorry.

Jill:
All the guys in the car were like let's go, we gotta get out of here, we gotta call 911, let's go.

Hailey:
And I don't know what I was thinking but I got in the car and I left.

Narrator:
With feelings of remorse, Hailey got a sober friend to drive her back to the scene, where she identified herself to the first police officer she saw. She was made to perform a field sobriety test, and blew a 0.19 on the Breath-a-Lyzer.

Hailey:
I never ever thought that I, daughter of 2 teachers, would be in jail, but I was.

Dad:
She called me, and she was hysterical. I couldn't understand what she was saying. All I got out of it was that there was an accident.

Hailey:
They took my mug shots, and gave me my jumpsuit, and walked me to my cell.

Dad:
She was being treated as a criminal, and she had done a criminal act.

Narrator:
Hailey's father didn't find out that she had left the scene of the crash until he read it in the newspaper the next day.

Dad:
It's just more serious, uncaring and um, wrong, you know, and disappointing.

Mom:
You know she had all the education in the world of what could happen, and why she would make such a terrible, terrible choice and how it changed everything in just that second.

Narrator:
Hailey was charged with intoxicated use of a vehicle, causing injury. She was sentenced to 2 years probation and 60 days in jail, which she was allowed to serve under house arrest. She was made to wear a bracelet on each ankle, one to monitor her location, and one to monitor whether she had any alcohol.

Hailey:
I think it was 150 bucks a week. My dad joked that it was the most expensive jewelry that I'd ever have, and it was.

Narrator:
After being fitted for the bracelet, police officers accompanied Hailey home to remove all alcohol and firearms from her father's house.

Dad:
My home was the jail. You know that's the way house arrest works.

Narrator:
The consequences of Hailey's conviction became clear over time. She tried to continue with college, but because she couldn't drive or find reliable transportation, she had to drop out. Because the accident made headlines in the local paper, she was afraid to go anywhere, feeling she would be recognized and rejected.

Hailey:
I was at a grocery store after the accident and people must not have known my face but they were talking about me.

Mom:
I mean it was in Burlen, Wisconsin, 5000 people, you've lived here since the day you were born, everybody knows you, your parents are teachers, um, it was just very unsettling.

Narrator:
Her fears proved real when she went to a festival out of town and ran into a group of people she knew from Burlen.

Hailey:
Somebody came up to me and said, what are you doing here? And I don't remember everything he said to me but one of the things he said was you should go kill yourself. And I lost it.

Dad:
And she was just devastated that um, she was treated that way, and of course her self-esteem was shot anyway.

Hailey:
I didn't want to deal with it, I didn't want people to tell me that because I was having a hard enough time. We started getting attorney letters in the mail. I hired my attorney, who told me that I couldn't contact Randy. I didn't know what was going on, I didn't know if he was dead or alive. It was awful.

Randy:
I had a concussion, so they thought I was going to be brain-damaged of some sort because of fatty tissues that went to my brain. I have pins in my knee and my ankle. When I got hit and the bone snapped and came right through the skin, so the only thing holding it there was muscle.

Hailey:
He has restrictions as far as lifting I think, I don't think he can stand for long periods of time.

Narrator:
In addition to the trauma and permanent injuries from the accident, Randy was financially accountable for close to $80,000 in medical bills, until Hailey's insurance paid almost 2 years later.

Randy:
I had like perfect credit, and after the accident, all the bills and everything started piling up, and my credit just took a big downfall, went right down the gutter.

Narrator:
Hailey's choice to drive that night caused a wave of irreversible damage. She paid the price in ways she never imagined.

Hailey:
I had the bracelet, I had probation fees, I had higher insurance, my dad's insurance went up.

Dad:
Four years later, she's still paying me back.

Mom:
There are things that Hailey has lost. Things that you can't replace, they're just, they're gone.

Hailey:
My self-esteem, I lost my youth almost.

Jill:
She was very down on herself, very depressed.

Mom:
Knowing that she hurt someone, I knew that was like the worst thing that could happen to her, and it has been.

Hailey:
Would I be able to forgive me if it was me? I don't know. I kind of pushed away from people.

Jill:
We're all 20, we're all kids. We make very bad decisions when we're under the influence.

Mom:
As they're growing up you think, I can help, I can make this better, and you can't.

Jill:
There's no specific kind of person that this happens to. I mean it can happen to anyone.

Hailey:
It's a poor decision, doesn't make the person stupid, or bad, or whatever, it's what the person does with it from there, and what the person learns from their mistake.
